text: And punishing them oftentimes in all the synagogues, I strove to make them blaspheme; and being exceedingly mad against them, I persecuted them even unto foreign cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: Whereupon as I journeyed to Damascus with the authority and commission of the chief priests,
speaker: Narrator

text: at midday, O king, I saw on the way a light from heaven, above the brightness of the sun, shining round about me and them that journeyed with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we were all fallen to the earth, I heard a voice saying unto me in the Hebrew language, Saul, Saul, why persecutest thou me? it is hard for thee to kick against the goad.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I said, Who art thou, Lord? And the Lord said, I am Jesus whom thou persecutest.
speaker: Narrator

text: But arise, and stand upon thy feet: for to this end have I appeared unto thee, to appoint thee a minister and a witness both of the things wherein thou hast seen me, and of the things wherein I will appear unto thee;
speaker: Narrator

text: delivering thee from the people, and from the Gentiles, unto whom I send thee,
speaker: Narrator

text: to open their eyes, that they may turn from darkness to light and from the power of Satan unto God, that they may receive remission of sins and an inheritance among them that are sanctified by faith in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore, O king Agrippa, I was not disobedient unto the heavenly vision:
speaker: Narrator

text: but declared both to them of Damascus first, and at Jerusalem, and throughout all the country of Judaea, and also to the Gentiles, that they should repent and turn to God, doing works worthy of repentance.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this cause the Jews seized me in the temple, and assayed to kill me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Having therefore obtained the help that is from God, I stand unto this day testifying both to small and great, saying nothing but what the prophets and Moses did say should come;
speaker: Narrator

text: how that the Christ must suffer, and how that he first by the resurrection of the dead should proclaim light both to the people and to the Gentiles.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as he thus made his defence, Festus saith with a loud voice, Paul, thou art mad; thy much learning is turning thee mad.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Paul saith, I am not mad, most excellent Festus; but speak forth words of truth and soberness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the king knoweth of these things, unto whom also I speak freely: for I am persuaded that none of these things is hidden from him; for this hath not been done in a corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: King Agrippa, believest thou the prophets? I know that thou believest.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Agrippa said unto Paul, With but little persuasion thou wouldest fain make me a Christian.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Paul said, I would to God, that whether with little or with much, not thou only, but also all that hear me this day, might become such as I am, except these bonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and they that sat with them:
speaker: Narrator

text: and when they had withdrawn, they spake one to another, saying, This man doeth nothing worthy of death or of bonds.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Agrippa said unto Festus, This man might have been set at liberty, if he had not appealed unto Caesar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was determined that we should sail for Italy, they delivered Paul and certain other prisoners to a centurion named Julius, of the Augustan band.
speaker: Narrator

text: And embarking in a ship of Adramyttium, which was about to sail unto the places on the coast of Asia, we put to sea, Aristarchus, a Macedonian of Thessalonica, being with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the next day we touched at Sidon: and Julius treated Paul kindly, and gave him leave to go unto his friends and refresh himself.
speaker: Narrator

text: And putting to sea from thence, we sailed under the lee of Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had sailed across the sea which is off Cilicia and Pamphylia, we came to Myra, a city of Lycia.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there the centurion found a ship of Alexandria sailing for Italy; and he put us therein.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we had sailed slowly many days, and were come with difficulty over against Cnidus, the wind not further suffering us, we sailed under the lee of Crete, over against Salmone;
speaker: Narrator

text: and with difficulty coasting along it we came unto a certain place called Fair Havens; nigh whereunto was the city of Lasea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when much time was spent, and the voyage was now dangerous, because the Fast was now already gone by, Paul admonished them,
speaker: Narrator

text: and said unto them, Sirs, I perceive that the voyage will be with injury and much loss, not only of the lading and the ship, but also of our lives.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion gave more heed to the master and to the owner of the ship, than to those things which were spoken by Paul.
speaker: Narrator

text: And because the haven was not commodious to winter in, the more part advised to put to sea from thence, if by any means they could reach Phoenix, and winter there; which is a haven of Crete, looking north-east and south-east.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the south wind blew softly, supposing that they had obtained their purpose, they weighed anchor and sailed along Crete, close in shore.
speaker: Narrator

text: But after no long time there beat down from it a tempestuous wind, which is called Euraquilo:
speaker: Narrator

text: and when the ship was caught, and could not face the wind, we gave way to it, and were driven.
speaker: Narrator

text: And running under the lee of a small island called Cauda, we were able, with difficulty, to secure the boat:
speaker: Narrator

text: and when they had hoisted it up, they used helps, under-girding the ship; and, fearing lest they should be cast upon the Syrtis, they lowered the gear, and so were driven.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as we labored exceedingly with the storm, the next day they began to throw the freight overboard;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the third day they cast out with their own hands the tackling of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when neither sun nor stars shone upon us for many days, and no small tempest lay on us, all hope that we should be saved was now taken away.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had been long without food, then Paul stood forth in the midst of them, and said, Sirs, ye should have hearkened unto me, and not have set sail from Crete, and have gotten this injury and loss.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now I exhort you to be of good cheer; for there shall be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.
speaker: Narrator

text: For there stood by me this night an angel of the God whose I am, whom also I serve,
speaker: Narrator

text: saying, Fear not, Paul; thou must stand before Caesar: and lo, God hath granted thee all them that sail with thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore, sirs, be of good cheer: for I believe God, that it shall be even so as it hath been spoken unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we must be cast upon a certain island.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the fourteenth night was come, as we were driven to and fro in the sea of Adria, about midnight the sailors surmised that they were drawing near to some country:
speaker: Narrator

text: and they sounded, and found twenty fathoms; and after a little space, they sounded again, and found fifteen fathoms.
speaker: Narrator

text: And fearing lest haply we should be cast ashore on rocky ground, they let go four anchors from the stern, and wished for the day.
speaker: Narrator

text: And as the sailors were seeking to flee out of the ship, and had lowered the boat into the sea, under color as though they would lay out anchors from the foreship,
speaker: Narrator

text: Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, Except these abide in the ship, ye cannot be saved.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the soldiers cut away the ropes of the boat, and let her fall off.
speaker: Narrator

text: And while the day was coming on, Paul besought them all to take some food, saying, This day is the fourteenth day that ye wait and continue fasting, having taken nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherefore I beseech you to take some food: for this is for your safety: for there shall not a hair perish from the head of any of you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when he had said this, and had taken bread, he gave thanks to God in the presence of all; and he brake it, and began to eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then were they all of good cheer, and themselves also took food.
speaker: Narrator

text: And we were in all in the ship two hundred threescore and sixteen souls.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had eaten enough, they lightened the ship, throwing out the wheat into the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when it was day, they knew not the land: but they perceived a certain bay with a beach, and they took counsel whether they could drive the ship upon it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And casting off the anchors, they left them in the sea, at the same time loosing the bands of the rudders; and hoisting up the foresail to the wind, they made for the beach.
speaker: Narrator

text: But lighting upon a place where two seas met, they ran the vessel aground; and the foreship struck and remained unmoveable, but the stern began to break up by the violence of the waves.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the soldiers’ counsel was to kill the prisoners, lest any of them should swim out, and escape.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the centurion, desiring to save Paul, stayed them from their purpose; and commanded that they who could swim should cast themselves overboard, and get first to the land;
speaker: Narrator

text: and the rest, some on planks, and some on other things from the ship. And so it came to pass, that they all escaped safe to the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we were escaped, then we knew that the island was called Melita.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the barbarians showed us no common kindness: for they kindled a fire, and received us all, because of the present rain, and because of the cold.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Paul had gathered a bundle of sticks and laid them on the fire, a viper came out by reason of the heat, and fastened on his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the barbarians saw the venomous creature hanging from his hand, they said one to another, No doubt this man is a murderer, whom, though he hath escaped from the sea, yet Justice hath not suffered to live.
speaker: Narrator

text: Howbeit he shook off the creature into the fire, and took no harm.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they expected that he would have swollen, or fallen down dead suddenly: but when they were long in expectation and beheld nothing amiss came to him, they changed their minds, and said that he was a god.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now in the neighborhood of that place were lands belonging to the chief man of the island, named Publius; who received us, and entertained us three days courteously.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was so, that the father of Publius lay sick of fever and dysentery: unto whom Paul entered in, and prayed, and laying his hands on him healed him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when this was done, the rest also that had diseases in the island came, and were cured:
speaker: Narrator

text: who also honored us with many honors; and when we sailed, they put on board such things as we needed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And after three months we set sail in a ship of Alexandria which had wintered in the island, whose sign was The Twin Brothers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And touching at Syracuse, we tarried there three days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from thence we made a circuit, and arrived at Rhegium: and after one day a south wind sprang up, and on the second day we came to Puteoli;
speaker: Narrator

text: where we found brethren, and were entreated to tarry with them seven days: and so we came to Rome.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from thence the brethren, when they heard of us, came to meet us as far as The Market of Appius and The Three Taverns; whom when Paul saw, he thanked God, and took courage.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when we entered into Rome, Paul was suffered to abide by himself with the soldier that guarded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass, that after three days he called together those that were the chief of the Jews: and when they were come together, he said unto them, I, brethren, though I had done nothing against the people, or the customs of our fathers, yet was delivered prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans:
speaker: Narrator

text: who, when they had examined me, desired to set me at liberty, because there was no cause of death in me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when the Jews spake against it, I was constrained to appeal unto Caesar; not that I had aught whereof to accuse my nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: For this cause therefore did I entreat you to see and to speak with me: for because of the hope of Israel I am bound with this chain.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they said unto him, We neither received letters from Judaea concerning thee, nor did any of the brethren come hither and report or speak any harm of thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: But we desire to hear of thee what thou thinkest: for as concerning this sect, it is known to us that everywhere it is spoken against.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they had appointed him a day, they came to him into his lodging in great number; to whom he expounded the matter, testifying the kingdom of God, and persuading them concerning Jesus, both from the law of Moses and from the prophets, from morning till evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: And some believed the things which were spoken, and some disbelieved.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they agreed not among themselves, they departed after that Paul had spoken one word, Well spake the Holy Spirit through Isaiah the prophet unto your fathers,
speaker: Narrator

text:
saying,
Go thou unto this people, and say,
By hearing ye shall hear, and shall in no wise understand;
And seeing ye shall see, and shall in no wise perceive:
speaker: Narrator

text:
For this people’s heart is waxed gross,
And their ears are dull of hearing,
And their eyes they have closed;
Lest haply they should perceive with their eyes,
And hear with their ears,
And understand with their heart,
And should turn again,
And I should heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be it known therefore unto you, that this salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles: they will also hear.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he abode two whole years in his own hired dwelling, and received all that went in unto him,
speaker: Narrator

text: preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching the things concerning the Lord Jesus Christ with all boldness, none forbidding him.
speaker: Narrator
